Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Scaling non-linear features
Input.posts:
Surely feature scaling breaks down when features are non-linear. For example, consider: size has a range of 1 to 100, so size^2 has a range 1 to 10000. If I select features x1 = size/100 x2 = size^2/10000 then for size=100, x1 = 1, x2 = 1 but for size=2, x1=0.02, x2=0.0004 That means the benefit of scaling is lost. Is there a better way to scale non-linear features to preserve scaling?
Upvotes:
0
Each feature has to be scaled by its own deviation, so $$size$$ is scaled by 100, as in your example, and $$size^2$$ by 10000. Both will fall in same range. I do not get your doubt.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
It's a good question, I can see where you are coming from. However, consider that you don't have to force the same scaling factor onto all features. In creating $$x^2$$ you are creating a different variable, but it is not created out of thin air, it is still tied to the original data but different. So to follow your example, you have two ranges, 1:100 and 1:10000. The shape of these functions will be quite different. Say you choose to scale the first range by 10, result is 1:10, and you sale the second by 1,000 and the result again is 1:10. But would you agree that the functions which now plot in the same range still have different shapes which replicate the original? Machine learning will still see them as different identities, somewhat correlated but not exactly, so each will have its own theta. Input.threadtitle: Why is predictions = X * Theta in the Control Statements video segment on functions?
Input.posts:
As specified in the title, I'm confused as to why predictions = X * theta, and why is theta = [0,1]? What does theta represent?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Theta is the vector of coefficients of your model. Let's say you have evaluated your training data thus far and discovered that theta is [2 3]'. This means that y (the dependent variable) is associated with 2 * the first feature in X plus 3 * the second feature in X. So if x1 is 4 and x2 is 1, then y must be 2*4 + 1*3 = 11. This has predicted only one observation. If you need predictions from multiple observations then you can stack the obs into an n by 2 matrix and use matrix algebra to calculate them all at the same time; in this case the observations X will be n by 2, theta is 2 by 1 so the result (X * theta) is n by 1 as required. When the professor imagines that theta is [0 1]' then this is saying that y does not depend on what is in the first value, just the second. It makes it easier to calculate in your head what the result should be, giving intuitive feedback. When he imagines that theta is [0 0]' then y does not depend on the values in X at all, hence the larger error or cost.

As specified in the title, I'm confused as to why predictions = X * theta, and why is theta = [0,1]? What does theta represent?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Theta is the vector of coefficients of your model. Let's say you have evaluated your training data thus far and discovered that theta is [2 3]'. This means that y (the dependent variable) is associated with 2 * the first feature in X plus 3 * the second feature in X. So if x1 is 4 and x2 is 1, then y must be 2*4 + 1*3 = 11. This has predicted only one observation. If you need predictions from multiple observations then you can stack the obs into an n by 2 matrix and use matrix algebra to calculate them all at the same time; in this case the observations X will be n by 2, theta is 2 by 1 so the result (X * theta) is n by 1 as required. When the professor imagines that theta is [0 1]' then this is saying that y does not depend on what is in the first value, just the second. It makes it easier to calculate in your head what the result should be, giving intuitive feedback. When he imagines that theta is [0 0]' then y does not depend on the values in X at all, hence the larger error or cost.

Hopefully, as the iterative process goes on, we will be closer and closer to the destination(that is, the point which evaluates to minimum of the cost function). X0 does play a role in this process. Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Why do we use the same learning rate for updating all thetas in one iteration instead of using multiple learning rates?
Input.posts:
Hi, As the title suggests, my question is: why not using multiple learning rates for updating different groups of thetas in one iteration. For example, theta_0 := theta_0 - alpha_0 * (derivative of cost function) theta_1 := theta_1 - alpha_1 * (derivative of cost function) ... ... It is because using a single learning rate makes gradient descent easier to implement? Or is it because using multiple learning rates leads to a biased result? Other than those, I see no reason why we couldn't use multiple learning rates in gradient descent. Thank you!
Upvotes:
1
Hello Bing Huang , I must admit I think your question is very well pointed !
Upvotes:
0
If you normalize the data I see no reason to do so.
Upvotes:
0
It would be fine to use multiple values for alpha - the rates of convergence for each individual theta would simply be different from using a single value for alpha. However, they both get the same job done, and considering one value for alpha is easier to implement, it seems pointless to add the added complexity of multiple alpha values.
Upvotes:
2
Scaling is equivalent to using different learning rate $$\alpha_{i}$$ for different feature. You just need to use one of the two tricks to help regression process avoid oscillating or diverging.
